newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgarian protesters burn effigy of premier.
newsitem.headline: Bulgarian protesters burn effigy of premier.

text.p: Thousands of opposition protesters demanding a new government to bring Bulgaria out of economic crisis burned a giant effigy of Prime Minister Zhan Videnov outside parliament on Thursday.

"All over the world, people are celebrating Christmas and all we have here is misery," Ilich Tsvetkov, a senior official of the opposition Union of Democratic Forces (UDF), told the crowd which had marched through the city centre from the National Palace of Culture.

The rally comes two days before a congress of Videnov's ruling Socialists, which will discuss calls by reformists for a new prime minister and cabinet, and for separation of the functions of party chairman and prime minister.
Earlier on Thursday, the UDF presented to parliament a "salvation declaration", which it wants debated and voted at an extraordinary session after the New Year holiday.

The UDF says a fixed exchange rate regime under discussion with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) will fail under the present government and it wants a new central bank board appointed to implement the currency board mechanism.
It wants parliament disbanded immediately and elections to be held in March, and negotiations with the IMF and World Bank on an economic programme to be conducted by an all-party team.
The Socialists have a secure majority in parliament and the UDF's proposals have not won much sympathy so far.
IMF experts who have been discussing technical details of the currency board are due to leave on Friday after presenting a draft report to the central bank.
An IMF negotiating mission must discuss the proposal with the government when details are finalised early next year.

Videnov said on December 9 the government planned a package of stabilisation measures to accompany introduction of a currency board, under which levs in circulation must be matched by central bank reserves.

The government has been slow to deliver on previous promises of structural reform but economists warn that a lev peg alone will not solve Bulgaria's problems unless it is accompanied by a serious commitment to measures delayed in the seven years since the end of one-party rule.
